author: fsamvura
title: Cardano Adoption in D.R. of Congo
description: Bitcoin scams have led the government to take a negative stance on crypto currencies that result in bans and discourage blockchain adoption.

assessments.note: This proposal is well presented and directly aligns with the challenge to create local community centers

The Congo holds great potential for Cardano blockchain solutions. Home to ~90M people, the potential for individual and state adoption is great.
An LCC in Kinshasa would therefore have a significant impact in central Africa.
Restoring Blockchain reputation in a key African country is fundamental. Creating an hub can be a good starting point.

Very interesting proposal, that could definitely support the mass adoption of Cryptocurrencies and also to change how it's seen in Congo. Only comment is that the continuity of the proposal after the fund money ends should be evaluated.

The proposer aims to create a local hub for developers and lawmakers to collaborate on blockchain use cases that will highlight the beneficial side of technology and break the negative stereotype of crypto in the local area. This community hub will likely be the first in the area and will act as a catalyst for innovation and change.

The proposal addresses the challenge, but one point needs to be clarified:

The idea of ​​the proposal is based on developers and policy-makers onboarding, with the aim of educating about blockchain and Cardano, so that Congo can have more people with the capacity to reverse the bans, however this idea is based on the declaration of the problem statement implying that the bans were caused by a reputation caused by scams, is that right? What information do we have to confirm that the ban was caused by this reason? We know that the cryptocurrency-related "bans" that took place in Nigeria were influenced by the government's monetary policy, as this was made public weeks ago. If a government's interest is to ban cryptocurrencies to preserve the country's financial system and prevent capital flight, the approach to reversing the ban is not as simple as demystifying scratches in the image of cryptos due to scams, the challenge would be much greater and would involve political interests.

I am raising this topic because the proposal's problem statement is subjective and doesn't make it clear what the scenario is in Congo, regardless of the reasons that are causing this crackdown, I think it is important that the idea be taken forward, because the proposal to educate people is the focus.
The proposal adresses the challenge effectively by creating a local office for meet ups in Congo. It aims to attract local coders for courses and further scale it through local connections.
A team has been formed, costs are reasonable and the specifics of the proposal have been ideated well.
There is a plan, the experience is relevant to start this up and the community will support this as Africa is a target region. I see no issues with implementation.
Risk management listed is quite low. However, also low participation is a scenario that could occur.

The proposal is very feasible. The plan is good as a first step, but its continuity should be assessed after fund money is ended. Mentioned experience is well related to the proposal. Roadmap says "Phase 1" but not "Phase 2". Not sure if it was an error or if Phase 2 would be in another Fund round.

The proposer claims to have some experience in the Haskell language as well as connection to WADA and local policymakers. This puts them in a unique position where they can leverage their knowledge and resources to achieve the target goal. Furthermore, $3000 USD is relatively a small amount of funding compared to the size of the budget in this category, and the community should see a great ROI. It is recommended that the proposer finds individuals willing to join as committed team members in order to split the workload.

There is a reasonable and structured plan, but there is no mention of which people will be involved in the proposal, it is crucial that we know who will be involved in the implementation of the proposal so that we can evaluate their professional experience and qualifications, I recommend the inclusion of these details and Linkedin (if possible).

The small team of two locals with some background in programming seems to be a reasonable start for the project. They have a marketing strategy and already a location they want to rent and build on. All in all, the aim seems in reach.
For such a low upfront cost, the ROI for the cardano ecosystem in DR Congo is worth it for the impact this could have on the locality

A clear roadmap with milestones, a plan, risk assessment and a funding detail.
Well done.

Proposing teams and partners look solid and experienced. There are also related proposals and a smartphone app is already in place. Full amount asked is also pretty low, so no big impact on the treasury fund

Based on the proposed plan, auditability is good. KPIs are well defined, but some numbers would benefit the proposal auditability. Challenges regarding government resistance against are mentioned and in part addressed, but this could be a bit more discussed.

The proposal includes sufficient information on budget and timeline breakdowns. The proposer also mentions that the project will require further funding, but they will not solely rely on the project Catalyst as a means to secure it. This proposal appears to be inline with the mission statement of the category it is in.

There is a clear roadmap, details on budget allocation, metrics, but there are no tangible KPIs.

The idea presented addresses the challenge, but without knowing who will be responsible for teaching about the technical aspects of blockchain and Cardano, it is difficult to measure the feasibility and success of implementation.

The proposal provides enough information on how they are planning to adress the challenge. They are renting an office, creating attention through local media to attract more potential Cardanians and adress potential risks. Only their meet ups could be layed out clearer.

solution: Create a local Blockchain Hub for Solution Design, for both developer and policy-maker onboarding.
experience:
- Junior Haskell teacher
- Family relations with local lawmaker
- Access to WADA Network ressources
- Community Engagement & Outreach
